title: R41763
content: Regulation is a fundamental government function, with federal agencies issuing thousands of rules annually on various topics. The costs of complying with these regulations are not included in the federal budget process, prompting interest in measuring total regulatory costs and benefits. Efforts such as the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011 aim to assess these costs and benefits, although it is challenging to accurately measure them. The difficulty in measuring total regulatory costs and benefits is highlighted, with challenges such as determining baselines and aggregating results from different studies. The Office of Advocacy within the Small Business Administration released a report in 2010 estimating the annual cost of federal regulations to be around $1.75 trillion, with previous reports in 1995, 2001, and 2005 estimating costs between $416 billion and $1.1 trillion. In 2001, W. Mark Crain and Hopkins estimated the annual cost of regulations in 2000 at $843 billion, and in 2005, Crain estimated annual regulatory costs in 2004 at about $1.1 trillion. The $1.75 trillion estimate of regulatory costs has been widely cited as evidence for regulatory reform legislation and congressional oversight actions. Critics argue that the estimate overstates the total cost of federal regulations. Crain and Crain developed the $1.75 trillion estimate by adding cost estimates for economic regulations, environmental regulations, tax compliance, and regulations involving safety and security. The estimated cost of economic regulations was more than 70% of the total regulatory costs. Economic regulations include restrictions and incentives that affect businesses' operations, both domestically and internationally. Crain and Crain used a Worldwide Governance Index to estimate the cost of economic regulations. The WGI regulatory quality index, developed by Aart Kraay, Massimo Mastruzzi, and Daniel Kaufmann, measures governments' ability to implement policies for private sector development. The index ranges from -2.5 to +2.5, with +2.5 indicating minimal regulation. In 2008, the US scored +1.579. Crain and Crain used regression analysis to study the impact of changes in the index on GDP per capita, finding a 9.4% change for a one-unit index change. In 2008, Crain and Crain found that a one-unit change in the WGI regulatory quality index represented a 9.4% change in real GDP per capita in the United States. They estimated that economic regulations reduced GDP by about $1.236 trillion.
